unnormalised: So, someone asked about the difference between rank and title in the Indian Armed Forces. It's a valid question, even if it sounds like a riddle wrapped in a Samosa! Basically, rank is like your level in a video game - Lt. Gen. Sharma outranks Brig. Verma, even if Verma's got a better sense of humour. Think of it as a ladder, with Sepoy at the bottom and Field Marshal (if we ever appoint one again) chilling at the very top.

unnormalised: Titles, on the other hand, are more about the job you're doing. COAS, for example, is a title - Chief of the Army Staff. Someone who's a Lt. General could hold that title. Or even a Maj. Gen. if there was some kind of…well, never mind. Imagine calling General Bakshi "Hey you!" during a war game...not gonna happen.

unnormalised: In short, rank is earned through service and promotions (and avoiding court martials!), while title is assigned based on your role. It's like the difference between being a "Graduate" (rank) and being a "Team Lead" (title). Hope that clears things up better than my attempt to explain nuclear physics to my grandma, bless her soul. She still thinks uranium is a type of flower.
